data.title: "Open File" when in replace preview diff mode does not work
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.1 (27492b6bf3acb0775d82d2f87b25a93490673c6d, 2017-09-14T16:26:20.018Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-96-generic (also affects macOS 10.12.6 and Windows 10 Enterprise build 15063.608)
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
EditorConfig|Edi|0.10.1
gc-excelviewer|Gra|1.1.15
r|Iku|0.4.6
python|don|0.7.0
git-project-manager|fel|1.4.0
php-debug|fel|1.11.1
php-intellisense|fel|1.5.1
phpcs|ika|0.7.0
Go|luk|0.6.65
ruby-rubocop|mis|0.4.0
cpptools|ms-|0.13.0
php-docblocker|nei|1.2.0
vscode-subword-navigation|ow|1.1.5
Ruby|reb|0.15.0
java|red|0.10.0
vscode-icons|rob|7.14.0
twig|wha|1.0.2
change-case|wma|1.0.0



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open "Search" pane and enter search/replace values
2. Click result to open "Replace Preview" editor
3. Click "Open File" at right of tab bar to open file for editing

Expected Result: An editable tab opens to the selected file.

Actual Result: No response.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Intellisense peek and navigation not working for global variables
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->I am writing api tests using javascript+mocha in visual studio code. I have created a file **testData.js** which contains

` exports.name = 'test';`
Now I have defined a **global variable** in setup.js and required that setup.js in **mocha.opts** file, which basically requires everything in setup.js and you can then access them without directly requiring them in your code.

`global.testData = require(./testData.js);`
Now in my **test.js**  file I am using

`name = testData.name;`
I am not able to traverse/peak to testData.js upon ctrl+click on testData.**name**. I am able to do so in webstorm.
But if I include below code in test.js then intellisense works fine but it defeats my purpose of using global variable-
```
const testData = require(./testData.js);
name = testData.name;
```
 How can I configure visual studio code to give intellisense in this scenario?

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version:1.16.1
- OS Version:macOS Sierra version 10.12.6

data.title: Break JavaScript syntax color
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04 LTS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Select sytax JS
2. Typewrite correct code:
```js
A.B = async(C, D, {
    E = 'F',
} = {}) => {
    // Comment
    if (!Func.J(C))
        throw new Error('Field C ...');
    if (!D || !OWNERS.includes(D))
        throw new Error('Field D ...');
};
``` 
3. Syntax coloring not work :(
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2098777/30962574-07fdb97e-a453-11e7-9ed6-3ac7cdf0d5f5.png)

data.title: Slightly increase MAX_IMAGE_SIZE

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: A workaround before https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/25122 is resolved. Lots of images have the size more than 1MB. For example, look at the sizes listed [here](https://apod.nasa.gov/apod/fap/image/1604/). A slightly larger value would solve the problem for most times.

data.title: New icons in stable
data.body:
**Verify (macOS, Linux, Windows) on STABLE (!):**
* the new icon is in and its the orange VSCode logo with full border shape (no "Rautenmuster"):

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/900690/30956317-355a9cbe-a437-11e7-865a-2be96d6f0915.png)


* Test the icon shows up in
  * Windows
    * [x] Task Bar
    * [x] Window
    * [ ]  File associations BUG: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/35380
    * [x] Letterpress background (when no editor is opened, visible in dark, light and HC themes)
    * [x] Welcome (icon for the tab)
    * [x] Installer
    * [x] Tile in the Start Menu ("pin to start"):

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/900690/30956252-0122befe-a437-11e7-947a-96f2a91be687.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/900690/30956255-04ec185a-a437-11e7-8b40-a3d5fc8606f5.png)

  * Linux
    * [ ] Dock
    * [ ]  Window
    * [x] Letterpress background (when no editor is opened, visible in dark, light and HC themes)
    * [x] Welcome (icon for the tab)
  * macOS
    * [x] Dock
    * [x]  File associations
    * [x] Letterpress background (when no editor is opened, visible in dark, light and HC themes)
    * [x] Welcome (icon for the tab)

Note: sometimes the OS decides to cash the old icon. In that case, try to uninstall and reinstall. On Windows there is a trick to flush the icon cache: from an admin powershell session, run (ls `$env:ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\[Shortcut].lnk).lastwritetime = get-date` where Shortcut is the VScode name.

data.title: Issue with tab Indentation
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->
Not able to work efficiently on VScode since tab setting does not work properly. Even after multiple solutions applied by googling. Now becoming frustrated for such a small issue since every 2 min I have to apply setting using command palette. Please help me to resolve this issue.

Also, when using tab, the width of tab character increases and decreases affecting the indentation of the file, when the cursor is focused on the line.

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8476966/30954250-11b543d4-a44d-11e7-8cba-5082952103dd.png)

- OS Version:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8476966/30954281-323186f4-a44d-11e7-8f35-3935e216a8f6.png)

GIF for better understanding:
![vscode_tab_issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8476966/30954526-1b00a98c-a44e-11e7-96c0-3962f5e75fe6.gif)

![vscode_tab_issue2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8476966/30954731-e17d446c-a44e-11e7-9dc8-dcd2e39dedab.gif)



Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set the tab related setting
2. Edit file and switch tab and come back to the previous tab



<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Import @angular in *.ts file - red underline in path.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 2.5.3-insiders.20170919
- OS Version: Win 7, 64-bit

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install angular via npm
2. Import it in ts module (eg. `import { NgModule } from '@angular/core';`)
3. You can see that VS Code underlines path (may it be issue with at sign in @angular?)

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes



Error does not occur if I import for example rxjs/Rx.

If I do instead `import { NgModule } from '@angular/core/core';` from example above,  it works, however it is not valid path, and app does not build.

It worked properly in previous build.

**Warning**: VS Code underlines import path after few seconds

data.title: [less] wrong colorization for some at-rules
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.17.0-insider (f7962f0682a76516df51de4856f8ccc5d8ad578a, 2017-09-20T05:24:33.599Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: Extensions are disabled
---

Steps to Reproduce:

The grammar wrongly identify some at-rules as variables, causing wrong colorization for them.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1330321/30954232-0002395c-a462-11e7-9e92-85f6ee90f46b.png)

Specifically,  `@charset`, `@keyframes`, `@page` `@namespace` and `@supports` are not supported. (I have checked all at-rules on https://css-tricks.com/the-at-rules-of-css/, `@document` is not supported by the language service at all)

It's worse if I use the Monokai theme, because it doesn't support less variables so they are just white. (for real variables, maybe I need to open another issue)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1330321/30954381-7efa7274-a462-11e7-84b0-84c4939a9714.png)

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes
